newsitem.title: CHINA: HK chief gets mixed, cautious press on policy plans.
newsitem.headline: HK chief gets mixed, cautious press on policy plans.

text.p: Hong Kong newspaper editorials ranged from praise to caution on Wednesday on chief executive Tung Chee-hwa's inaugural speech setting a policy blueprint for this newly-autonomous region of China.
On the first day of Hong Kong's reversion to Beijing rule, the post-colonial leader proposed initiatives in housing, education and economic policy fields.
Some of his aims were too ambitious, the English-language South China Morning Post said. "He has an inspiring vision for the SAR (Special Administrative Region), but some goals may be elusive."
"There were times when his words had the ring of a politician seeking election, rather than a leader who has the future of 6.3 million people in his hands," it said.
The chief executive's views were shared by the Hong Kong people, but he might find it difficult to put substance into form, the English-language Hong Kong Standard said.
"It is in bringing this vision to reality that there are some doubts," it said.
Chinese language newspapers echoed this view.

"The 'One country, two systems' concept is encouraging, but there is still a long and harsh way to put it into reality," Ming Pao Daily News said. "There is no need for either pessimism or praise-singing."
Wen Wei Po, a Hong Kong-based Beijing mouthpiece, hailed Tung's speech as a foundation for continued prosperity, under a headline, "Hong Kong will have a better tomorrow."
"Hong Kong people absolutely have the power and wisdom to plan Hong Kong's future," it said.
Other newspapers said Tung gave only a brief sketch of his future policy on issues.
"He did not say much about concrete measures," the Apple Daily said.
"The speech might disappoint those who had expected a major announcement from him," it said.
